I dislike games that use this "everything but the kitchen sink" design philosophy. It reminds me of PeeWee Herman's breakfast machine that allows him to crack an egg in a convoluted but flashy 20 step process.

In this game you're trying to fill up a board with rectangular pieces that you get from placing workers on one of forty different action spaces. These spaces might give you rectangles for free, or you might have to play a card or roll a dice to get rectangles, or you could upgrade a rectangle you already have into a slightly better rectangle.

The huge board with it's sheer number of actions feels grandiose at first sight, but everything is so interchangeable that to me it felt like it lacked depth. All of those choices drown out any sense of tension. In other worker placement games, there's a push and pull between needing a space, but wanting to wait because you might get more out of it if nobody else takes it. Here, if someone takes the space you want, it's a mild inconvenience because you can still easily go to several other similar spaces. The fact that it's all for a simplistic tetrimino-like game, make the whole experience feel underwhelming for me.

One more example of how extraneous mechanics there are: you have to feed your people. But it's nearly impossible to not feed your people because the game is so generous with food during the income phase. There are ideas here that I enjoy. For example the job cards, and how you use more workers for better spaces. I just don't feel like it's worth the effort of setting up and explaining this game.

Multiplayer solitaire, ap prone (while the choices aren’t that interesting), abstract and both feels and is long. But if you love complicated tetris, you might enjoy it. Love Many of Uwe’s designs, but this one is not for me. I despise it to be honest.

I know that a lot of people enjoy sandbox euros, but I'm not one of them... at all! This has the thinnest veneer of a theme, and all the Tetris-like actions kill what little is there.

The fact that the game has such a huge amount of actions to choose from just seems crazy to me! I prefer much fewer, and streamlined actions, but with complex gameplay interactions. In A Feast for Odin all those actions are further complicated by the fact that my aging eyes can barely make them out, size-wise and graphically (more contrast would help).

What I like:
- Exploration of the sandbox. Finding viable strategies.
- One of the only games with a solo mode in which I actually enjoy the solo mode. I think this is mostly due to the puzzling / polyominoes aspect of the game.

What I dislike:
- A bit too sandboxy for my taste, hence, too much choice, and some strategies are clearly better than others.
- Dice luck during certain action spaces.
- Feeding is more an afterthought or gimmick compared to Agricola.
- Soooo many options, so many pieces.

Good worker placement / tile laying game, but the setup & teardown time are a killer. Also, there are more enjoyable tile laying games that are much quicker (Patchwork, My City, My Island).

A Feast for Odin is a needlessly complex game--it has an interesting puzzle, and I'd maybe even like to play it again, but it'll never be a favorite.

I hated A Feast for Odin the first time I played it -- and yet, like Agricola -- it's kind of lingered in my mind in the time since. This is a very complex game with a lot going on, but my second play helped me to see 'the systems behind the systems' and understand the point of the game a little better.

At its heart, this is still an optimization game, and it still feels like there's a lot of needless obfuscation in the mechanics, but it's at least inoffensive. And the puzzle does have that little knife twist that keeps you thinking about how you could have played better after you finish playing.

I'd still take Terra Mystica or Russian Railroads over it any day, though.

I have been saying for a few years now that I would really like to see Uwe Rosenberg come up with some fresh ideas. His games have became so samey samey that they just feel completely derivative of his own past designs. The massive amount of action choices started with Agricola which morphed to even more action spaces with Le Havre which he put on steroids to come up with Ora et Labora and then Caverna. With this new rendition, we are still collecting a bazillion resources

Definitely my bag as I love tetris puzzles, heavy Euros, and the Vikings theme. Drawbacks are the massive amount of cardboard counters and large footprint but this is a good game. Animals are weak in the base game but this is remedied by Norwegians. This is low interaction so can be a relaxing alternative when I want to exercise the brain without being smashed to pieces.

This game shouldn't work for me, but it sort of does. It's a mish-mash of polyomino puzzling which I actively dislike, worker placement which is rarely interesting to me, and "stay in your lane" pre-baked strategies that lead to an almost completely solitaire experience. Despite all this, the feeling I get from looking at all the possibilities is immersive and exciting, the sense of exploration/expansion and the sprinkling of risk-taking shines through to bring this mess to life. A Feast for Odin is in the rarified air of games that are so audacious and yet so crystallized I almost can't even believe they exist.

I'm clearly not a Rosenberg fan. Like his other top games, I find the theme, look, and 'feed your people' mechanisms boring. Sure, there are tough decisions. But I don't find any of them particularly fun.

This has the same giant board of actions that I dislike in many of Uwe's games. But it's mitigated by having a bit more differentiation between the actions than some of his other games: I find it easier to chart a path between those actions with some goal in mind. And I've seen in my plays that there are different viable strategies. There's still not a lot to constrain or guide you towards any strategy, apart from the occupations, which aren't as strong as I'd like.

The polyomino aspect of the game makes a nice puzzle. It's interesting to see that here since polyominoes are big part of many of his lighter games.

I can see why fans of many of Uwe's other games like this one so much. It's unique but incorporates a lot of features from his other games. I just happen to not like some of those features.

See my thoughts about other Uwe Rosenberg games in my Uwe Rosenberg Games I've Played geeklist.

Initial Impressions: I was afraid the sheer number of actions in this game would make it extremely inelegant. I did ignore several of the submechanisms in the game on my play, but at least the core game play loop isn't too overbearing. It also helps that the feeding in this game is pretty mild unlike Agricola, so if you miss out on some optimizations in the other submechanisms you aren't drowning in point debt. I was surprised how much I enjoyed this game. Another thing I didn't think I would like is the covering up your aspect, as I don't like too strong of a polynomio spatial aspect. But that also isn't too bad; it's only about the level of Patchwork or even less; people who really like polynomios might be disappointed in the tile laying in this game. I like that there are occupation cards like in Agricola, and also the excitement of the hunting/whaling/raiding actions, even if the risk in those actions are very on rails.

I wonder if the game being a lot less tight than Agricola will eventually make it less tense. Or maybe it will just remove the stress in that game. Only time will tell, but I think its potential is about the same level.

EDIT: After more plays, each action outside the get new things to cover up feels too closely cover up 2-3 spaces, rather than doing different things.

Another magic trick is flip the boat tiles, I mean I got to know they can be flipped and worth almost triple points kind of in the middle of the game, so next time maybe start from take livestock tiles and boat tiles and that's it. Kurzrezension:
"Ein Fest für Odin" ist ein Puzzlespiel der Superlative mit einem Arbeiter-Einsatz-Mechanismus, um sich die Puzzleteile aus der Materialfülle der Schachtel zu holen!

Spielablauf:
Im Grunde ist das Spiel sehr einfach. Wer an der Reihe ist, setzt einen seiner Wikinger auf eines der vielen Aktionsfelder. Dort erhält der Spieler verschiedene Plättchen, die allesammt Ressourcen oder Nahrung in verschiedenen Formen darstellen. Diese Plättchen können dann - von unten links beginnend - auf das eigene Tableau gelegt werden, wo sie Minuspunkte abdecken. Um die eigene Wikingermannschaft zu sättigen, ist eine ausgewogene Ernährung wichtig, die auf dem rechten Feld des Tableaus gepuzzelt werden muss, dabei ist zu beachten, dass gleiche Farbplättchen nicht aneinander gerenzen dürfen, um Fleisch und Gemüse in der Waage zu halten...
Münzen sind Joker, die als 1x1 großes Plättchen in jede Ritze passt und ebenfalls zur Ernährung der Mannschaft diesen darf.
Je voller der eigene Spielplan wird, desto mehr Einkommen generiert dieser im Spielverlauf und desto weniger Minuspunkte am Spielende
Nach einer festen Anzahl Runden endet das Spiel und alle Spieler können ihren Flickenteppich aus Fellen, Fleisch, dazwischen liegenden Münzen, Met und dergleichen betrachten. Wer jetzt die meisten Punkte gesammelt hat, gewinnt.

Meinung:
"Ein Fest für Odin" ist im wahrsten Sinne des Wortes ein Schlachtfest. Das Spiel hat mir in Ansätzen tatsächlich Spaß gemacht und wenn die Puzzlerrei nicht wäre, wäre es vermutlich sogar ein tolles Spiel, welches ich gerne wieder spielen möchte!
Ich weiß es wirklich nicht, kann mir aber absolut nicht vorstellen, dass die Wikinger damals ihre Beute mit veredeltem Essen und Strickjäckchen auf dem Boden verstreut und mit Silbermünzen und Granit veredelt haben.
Eigenartig finde ich auch, dass sechs Arbeiter von einem ganzen Stück "Wal" nicht satt werden, aber von einem Humpen Met und drei Halme Stroh sehr wohl? Das liegt daran, dass die Spielmechanik längliche Nahrung vor breiten bevorzugt.
Ich finde das Thema völlig aufgesetzt, aber okay, es ist ein Euro-Game!
Man nehme, was man kriegen kann, konzentriert sich dabei auf die größten Plättchen und wertet dieses dann so weit auf, dass es irgendwie auf die eigene Insel passt, streut noch ein paar Münzen dazwischen, sodass frühzeitig ein hohes Einkommen generiert wird, mit dem man in künftigen Runden wieder Lücken stopfen kann und bekommt seinen Plan schnell voll.
Wem das Spaß macht - mir nicht wirklich - dem sei "Ein Fest für Odin" empfohlen. Ich bin froh, es mal gespielt zu haben, brauche es aber kein weiteres Mal.

I enjoyed my plays of A Feast for Odin, but don't really see any reason to return to it. To me, the fun was in the discovery, pulling one of the 5732 levers that the game provided and seeing what happens. The occupation cards were my favorite part, and didn't seem to be utilized enough (probably because I'm not very good at the game). I'd play again if asked, but will never seek out a game.

Ideal Player Count: 3

This game mixes the mechanics of Agricola (for the worker placement part, 70% of the gameplay) and Patchwork (for the placement of tiles on a 2D board, 30% of the gameplay). It features deep strategy and many choices, with rules that are not that hard to learn.

Even though a worker placement is naturally interactive, the set of choices is so big that I feel like you always have something nice to do. Also, the different spaces on the board don't change and evolve during the game, so it feels a bit static. From game to game, the setup is almost the same each time which also don't really motivate you in changing your strategy once you found a good one. For these reasons, the worker placement part is less interesting than Agricola in my opinion, even though it's still great.

On the other hand, the resources part and the tiles placement is more interesting, because you have to think all the time about the tiles that you need, and how evolved you need them, You can also buy new islands that you will also be able to fill with tiles, and all of that together really makes it very fun and complex.

Overall, I think this game is very similar to Agricola since these are two complex worker placement games, and in my opinion they both shine in different aspects.

A heavier worker placement game where players are primarily placing a worker and executing actions (mostly gaining resources/money, exchanging x to y, raiding/hunting to gain polyomino pieces to place onto your board). Everything done is to feed your workers and fill in your board with polyomino pieces which affects money income every round. After 7 rounds, player who scores the most points wins.

A multiplayer solitaire efficiency puzzle! This time featuring polyominos, dice, and a TON of options!

A Feast For Odin is fun: there's a veritable cornucopia of different ways to approach the game, with the goal of collecting enough polyomino tiles to fill out your player boards as best you can. It's a low interaction, fairly low randomness efficiency puzzle. For me, this would lead to a game with low replayability, were it not for the various cards, which really make this game. Not enough to hype it up over more interactive experiences, but enough to make each game different, and have interesting decisions. I still worry that at experienced tables this "sandbox" of options dwindles rapidly in favour of the established, most efficient paths, but luckily I am not an experienced player.

It's one of the better heads down experiences I've had, but it's not as exciting as I'd hoped. As a solo puzzle it IS fun: there's a ton to explore here. But I'll always favour more interactive games over another MPS Euro that has more pieces than the last.
Probably to go

This game is the biggest worker placement and tetris game from uve. The way it plays it kinda feels like a point salad. You are trying to get pieces to cover negative point spaces and also get more resources by doing that tactically. There is tons of spaces and special abilities. That part of the game is good but not very innovative. My problem with the game is luck in getting gear, hunting, profession etc. It doesn't feel nice when you are drawing cards and you get something that is worthless.

Having played the game significantly more since my initial review (thanks BGA) I'm happy to bump this up to a 7.5, but I'm still not particularly excited about your options in the game. If you're not raiding, you're not winning. I have yet to see any combo of occupations that makes a no-raid strategy feasible. I guess then the game becomes about how you're optimizing outside of raiding? Which, okay, sure, that's fun, but it's still coming in below Agricola for me, where your occupations and bonuses are shaping your whole game, rather than just some subplot. It's good. Won't be rushing out to buy it.
Update: raiding began to feel pretty stale again,.still a good game but I'm rapidly cooking on it for how excited I am to see it on the table.
I liked it, but I would rather play Agricola any day. Mostly played Solo, but it felt like it was too wide open and not punishing enough.

My favorite Uwe game and an all-time favorite, though farming seems pretty underpowered. All the fun is in exploration and conquest. Was a 10 for a while but due to the static, multi-player solitaire nature of the game, it's back to a 9. Solo mode is ingenious but it would be nice if more variability could be added. The first early turns can start feeling like a samey optimization puzzle and the real fun doesn’t kick in until later turns. But I had to play this 20 times solo before I started feeling that way.
I liked it, but I much prefer Agricola's tense competition for spaces.

I sold this game because I love Caverna more. Having both just seems gluttonous. I like the theme of Caverna better, farming and mining makes me happy raiding and pillaging makes me feel icky. But it's an outstanding game.
After some plays, it really needs the expansion to fix the location balances. I feel like I only use half of the locations on the board.

Choose from a wide variety of actions (trading, hunting, pillaging, building etc.) in order to bring goods into your home (and possibly other lands you have explored) and fill your board tetris-like with those goods. A very simple solo rule (alternating colours) allows for similar experience to multi-player.

Another great addition to the Uwe Rosenberg worker placement series. This combines Agricola and Patchwork, making the WP less competitive but adding the spatial puzzle for additional solitaire strategy.

This game is excellent, but a bit un polished without the expansion, the expansion is absolutely needed to smooth out the card luck and ensure the card draw is interesting and engaging, without being a luck fest. Even with the fix of the expansion, the cards are still a little lucky, but it's nowhere near as game breaking.

For the most part the WP feels more like action points, although there are some highly desirable spaces that you will compete for, normally you stay out of each others way. Still plenty of interaction, but more the style of interaction where your opponents will cause you to pivot and adjust, rather than just blocking or shutting you out.

The meat of the game is in the spatial puzzle, its really well done. You need to balance, unlocking bonuses and income with the long term goal of filling up your board. It might be better at times to just cover over bonuses, and you have to be careful where you place greens on your boards or you can lock yourself up a bit. I also enjoy how food can be used to fill up boards, but only on certain things.

My favourite decision in the game is what houses and islands to take, although as I played more I realised that the game strongly revolves a rush to get islands, reminiscent of the rush for the 3rd worker in Agricola, which is kinda disappointing and reduced the feel of every game being different.

The only other issue I have with this game, is it lacks any excitement or drama to lift it into my favourites, nothing you do every feels really special, but its a consistently relaxing and satisfying game, which is not a bad thing sometimes.
10 with the expansion

The more I play the more I enjoy the game, still trying out different strategies each time. My second favorite Uwe game after Agricola.

Thoughts: Honestly could be a 10. No game has a more satisfying end product—I literally take pictures of the finished boards. Paths are nearly endless and the expansion elevates it further, easily making this top 3. Wife also loves it, which seals the deal. Peak Uwe and one of the best games ever made.

+ A Feast for Odin: The Norwegians

Just like his other games, fun to play regardless of winning or losing. Placing and planning, searching for options, watching things grow. The occupation cards and sheds are probably needed so it doesn't feel so solvable (not that I can solve it).

This is the second game I played (not including the trashy, popular stuff you play as a child) back in 2018. It showed me how fabulously interesting boardgames could be, that there were many pathways you could take, that your evening does not have to be determined by dice rolls, and that a game could last 1-2 hours and be thrilling all the way through. This game is accessible and is one I will always be happy to get to the table.

Tolle Kombination aus Worker-Placement und puzzeln. Der Aktionsplan mit ca. 60 möglichen Aktionen wirkt erstmal erschlagend, aber man kommt dann erstaunlich schnell rein. Über die Karten kommt Variabilität rein. Schöne Lernkurve. Zu zweit hervorragend zu spielen, auch solo sehr spannend und herausfordernd.

P: 1-4, T: 1-2 h

Update: own now, quickly becoming one of our favorites. Wife likes it more than Agricola and it really doesn't take as long to play as I feared.

Might be a 10 and I might still be a noob
This game is (almost) perfection. So much choice, so much freedom, and a great theme. It makes me really happy.

i think this is probably my #2 favorite game? i always have at least one game of it going on bga, it's always given as an option for "what do we want to play tonight" with my wife, and it has decent odds of being a game we play when we have more people. i am literally always down play this game.
it's just so perfectly puzzley, not just the literal puzzle of placing goods on your boards but the puzzle of how everything works together. how do your actions segue together? how do your bonuses from your islands help you further your game plan? what's the appropriate timing to do that thing you're trying to do? so many nested questions that leave my head spinning in the best way possible.
player interaction largely boils down to "do the thing x player wanted to do" but is anything more than that needed? having that be a constant consideration makes this feel like more than the multiplayer solitaire it is often derided as imho.
my only complaint is that the sheer number of actions available leads to analysis paralysis for me, even when i have a pretty firm game plan in place. but if my only complaint is "there's so many options!" then i don't think i have much to really be complaining about.
- Not sure if it will stay in the long term
